The steady infantry of the Romans swept before it the motley gatherings of mercenariae brought against them in the field, and Hier0, who had little to hope except a choice of masters, changed sides after a cam- paign or two, and joined the stronger‚ whose success , 116 dreaded least. But the war in Sicily could not be decided by hard fighting on the open field. A period of slow sieges followed, and Rome’s success was more than balanced by the fleets of privateers which ravaged the coasts of Italy and ruined all its trade, while Carthage was mistress of the seas. Then Rome de· cided to create a navy. She could not raise at once skilled sailors to manoeuvre with precision, and more than 6116 great fieet was lost by the rashness or inex- perience of her captains: but she could so build as 116 enable them to grapple and board each ship that came alongside, and to decide the battle by sheer weight of discipline and numbers. Her navy so constructed swept the seas, and landed her legions under Regulus almost within sight of Carthago, but the rash confi· dence of general and senate while dictating haughty terms of peace kept the weakened army long inactive, to be crushed at length by overpowering numbers.
